thread.title: Oregon Ducks' winning streak, and bowl hopes, put to the test against Washington Huskies: game preview
thread.title_full: Oregon Ducks' winning streak, and bowl hopes, put to the test against Washington Huskies: game preview | OregonLive.com

author: Andrew Greif | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Oregon Ducks' winning streak, and bowl hopes, put to the test against Washington Huskies: game preview
text:
Oregon vs. Washington
Time: 7:30 p.m. Saturday
Where: Husky Stadium, Seattle
Records: Oregon (3-3, 1-2 Pac-12); Washington (3-2, 1-1)
Coaches: Mark Helfrich, third year at Oregon (27-7); Chris Petersen, second year at Washington (11-8 at UW, 103-20 overall)
Latest Line: Washington by 2
On Air: TV on ESPN2, radio on radio on KXTG (750 AM, 102.9 FM), KUGN-AM (590), Sirius 136, XM 201
What's At Stake: For Oregon, this represents a potential 12th consecutive victory in the series, a chance to move one win closer to bowl eligibility and -- if quarterback Vernon Adams Jr. returns from his two-game break -- a test of whether Oregon's offense is back to its old ways against the Pac-12 Conference's toughest defense.
UO offense vs. Washington defense: The matchup on which this game hinges is whether Oregon's rushing offense will be slowed by Washington's Pac-12 best rushing defense -- and if it's the case, whether UO's ailing passing game can make the plays it needs to take pressure of running back Royce Freeman and Co. Oregon's 318 rushing yards per game rank sixth-most in the FBS and Freeman's 32 rushes for 10-plus yards are the best of any back. Backup Taj Griffin, the true freshman, has made UO coaches look like geniuses by increasing his role the past two games, as he's gained 206 yards on 22 carries. Yet UW has reloaded despite the losses of NFL draft picks Hau'oli Kikaha and Danny Shelton along its defensive line and is holding opponents to a Pac-12-best 121.6 yards each outing. Buck linebacker Travis Feeney earned Pac-12 player of the week honors after seven tackles, 3.5 for loss, against USC. The secondary is patrolled by onetime UO commit Budda Baker, who has recovered from an ankle injury. Keeping the secondary honest will require a passing game with a pulse, however. Only one Ducks receiver has a 100-yard game this season, Bralon Addison's 138 against Michigan State, which was also the last time UO threw deep with regularity. UO has been coy about the availability of quarterback Vernon Adams Jr. and receiver Darren Carrington, but this could be the weekend UO integrates both back into the offense. If they play, Oregon could win in a runaway. If Adams doesn't, an upset could be brewing.
 The Official Visit Podcast: Starting Vernon Adams? In this week's edition of The Official Visit podcast, Tyson Alger and Andrew Greif discuss whether or not Vernon Adams Jr. should play this week against Washington.
UO defense vs. Washington offense: Receiver and safety Charles Nelson is projected to play two ways for the second straight week, after his 12 tackles against Washington State led UO. At 5-foot-8 and 170 pounds he doesn't cut the typical profile of a long, tall safety such as 6-3 Tyree Robinson, but his speed to the ball was evident, though he did miss a touchdown-saving tackle against the Cougars. Nelson is listed as a co-starter alongside Reggie Daniels on the latest depth chart, after Daniels -- who played the most snaps of any UO defender in 2014 -- did not start against Utah and did not play against WSU for undisclosed reasons. After allowing 500-plus passing yards to the Cougars, Oregon now prepares for a true freshman quarterback in Jake Browning who leads one of the country's least-prolific passing attacks. Browning is only the second modern UW quarterback to start as a true freshman, joining Marques Tuiasosopo against Oregon in 1997, and ranks 73rd nationally in passing efficiency. Jaydon Mickens, a 5-foot-11 senior receiver, is third all-time in career UW receptions and has acted as a safety valve for Browning. The key for Oregon's front seven, which recorded a season-high seven sacks and 13 tackles for loss last week, is containing freshman running back Myles Gaskin. Gaskin rushed for 134 yards and a touchdown against USC.
Did you know: Oregon has used the same starting offensive line for three consecutive games and five of its six this season. It took UO until the eighth game of its injury plagued 2014 season to field the same starting lineup three straight games.
Individual Matchup to Watch: Washington left tackle Trey Adams vs. Oregon defensive end DeForest Buckner. Adams is the first true freshman to start at left tackle in Washington history, and out of 306 tackles across the FBS is ranked No. 280 by PFF College. He won't often block Buckner alone but should receive the brunt of his pressure. Buckner is on track to become a first-round NFL draft choice this spring, and is the country's highest-rated interior defender, according to PFF College.
Mark Helfrich previews Oregon at Washington At his Tuesday press conference Helfrich talked about playing at Washington on Saturday.
Key Stat: Oregon hasn't lost consecutive games in the same season since November 2007 and hasn't lost to Washington in 11 games.
They Said It: "Hopefully we can make it a rivalry. Because it hasn't been for the last decade," Jimmy Lake, Washington defensive backs coach.
Prediction: Washington 31, Oregon 28
-- Andrew Greif
agreif@oregonian.com
@andrewgreif
